data.title: SCM preview: Consistent .git/index.lock: File exists
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (04d25e446f52c8425ca45da966b28795f3585a3c, 2017-02-21T17:26:02.548Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|autofilename|JerryHong|0.1.3|
|vscode-simple-icons|LaurentTreguier|0.10.0|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.11|
|azure-cli|chrmarti|0.3.0|
|regex|chrmarti|0.0.7|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.5|
|ghlink|dt|0.0.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|vscode-scss|mrmlnc|0.6.1|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.9.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.2|
|diff|rafaelmaiolla|0.0.1|
|vscode-open-in-github|sysoev|1.3.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal while Code is running
2. `git pull --rebase` or similar commands
3. -> Fails due to the lock being taken

This previously happened only very rarely, with the SCM preview it consistently reproduces.

data.title: Insiders is nearly unusable on Linux

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (25c55638340197fc9c8767aba9d32a0c29ccf68a, 2017-02-21T07:18:14.781Z) - OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-34-generic - CPUs: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-5500U CPU @ 2.40GHz (4 x 2900) - Memory (System): 11.64GB (2.73GB free) - Memory (Process): 199.66MB working set (200.91MB peak, 129.13MB private, 70.53MB shared) - Load (avg): 1, 1, 1 - VM: 0% - Initial Startup: no - Screen Reader: no - Empty Workspace: no - Timings: |Component|Task|Time (ms)| |---|---|---| |renderer|window.loadUrl() => begin to require(workbench.main.js)|2426| |renderer|require(workbench.main.js)|712| |renderer|create extension host => extensions onReady()|930| |renderer|restore viewlet|1216| |renderer|restore editor view state|899| |renderer|overall workbench load|1467| |main + renderer|start => extensions ready|4146| |main + renderer|start => workbench ready|4629| --- I don't know what's going on but I've been noticing this on and off for a few days. Occasionally windows are incredibly slow, I'm talking 2 frames a second and 2-5 second delay on key/mouse. Start up performance is also pretty terrible in comparison to stable but it's using the product that's the worst problem. Here's a timeline of my trying to trigger a quick open: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/23178605/f157efd0-f81f-11e6-897c-264a1db6142b.png) Notice the frames that take ~1 second to compute. Note that this happens with `--disable-extensions` as well. Additional Steps to Reproduce (if any): 1. Open a second window (seems to happen mainly when there are 2+ windows?) --- Here is a performance report under similar circumstances on stable: - VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:44:55.542Z) - OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-34-generic - CPUs: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-5500U CPU @ 2.40GHz (4 x 2899) - Memory (System): 11.64GB (1.72GB free) - Memory (Process): 150.06MB working set (150.59MB peak, 85.19MB private, 64.88MB shared) - Load (avg): 1, 1, 1 - VM: 0% - Initial Startup: no - Screen Reader: no - Empty Workspace: no - Timings: |Component|Task|Time (ms)| |---|---|---| |renderer|window.loadUrl() => begin to require(workbench.main.js)|159| |renderer|require(workbench.main.js)|726| |renderer|create extension host => extensions onReady()|787| |renderer|restore viewlet|343| |renderer|restore editor view state|1| |renderer|overall workbench load|593| |main + renderer|start => extensions ready|1749| |main + renderer|start => workbench ready|1505|

data.title: Option to show project path in title bar
data.body:
In viewing the new options in 1.10.0 for display in the window titlebar, I would rather see the path **within my project**  (or "appName" as you call it) instead of the full disk path.

For example, for an open file like
`/Users/stevelombardi/github/designsystem-3/app/assets/sass/documentation/_content.scss`
I don't need to see `/Users/stevelombardi/github/` as every project has that.  

However, seeing this in my titlebar might be helpful: 
`designsystem-3/app/assets/sass/documentation/_content.scss`
So I can see where **in my app** this file is.

I see no way to configure this.

data.title: Test: Git as an SCM provider
data.body:
Test for #18615

- [x] Windows @sandy081 
- [x] OS X @ramya-rao-a 
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 

Complexity: 5

Make sure you `Enable SCM Preview` in the command palette. Most of this code is new, make sure you give a it proper smoke test:

- Git output channel
- Dirty diff (gutter decorations)
- SCM viewlet
  - Click, keyboard nav
  - Title, inline, context menu actions
  - Commit box
- Git status bar
- Merge conflict decorations
- Fetch happens automatically, unless configured otherwise
- SCM Viewlet shows progress during operations
- Global commands
- Editor title actions
- No repo workspace shows "Git Init" action
- Scoped git workspace: open a folder within a git repo, everything should work
- Editor selections
  - Staging, unstaging (global commands)
  - Reverting (global command)
- If you set a [git commit template](https://robots.thoughtbot.com/better-commit-messages-with-a-gitmessage-template) it is picked as a default value for the commit box
- If you use a repository that requires authentication, you get prompted for credentials
- Clone global command

data.title: Test: Put theme configuration to settings.json
data.body:
Test for #7358

- [x] any os @joaomoreno 
- [x] any os @roblourens 

Complexity: 2

Theme configuration is now part of the settings. 
```
  // Specifies the color theme used in the workbench.
  "workbench.colorTheme": "Default Dark+",

  // Specifies the icon theme used in the workbench.
  "workbench.iconTheme": null,
```

- Test that changing the theme can still be done through commands and the `Preferences > Color Theme` and `Preferences > File Icon Theme` menu items
   - the setting will be applied to the user settings unless it is already defined in the workspace settings, then it will be applied to the workspace settings
   - if the setting matches the default theme, the setting is removed rather than set
- Test that you can change the theme in the settings editor
   - intellisense, hover should be there
- Test that reloading VSCode restores the correct theme
   - there should not be any color flickering, unless the theme is configured in the workspace
- Test that migrating from a older version of VSCode (1.9 or less) works.
   - no change of theme
   - theme is set in the settings

Older version of vscode:
- [win](https://az764295.vo.msecnd.net/insider/27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af/VSCode-win32-1.9.0-insider.zip)
- [macos](https://az764295.vo.msecnd.net/insider/27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af/VSCode-darwin-insider.zip)
- [linux 32](https://az764295.vo.msecnd.net/insider/27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af/code-insider-1.9.0-1485950021_i386.tar.gz)
- [linux 64](https://az764295.vo.msecnd.net/insider/27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af/code-insider-1.9.0-1485949086_amd64.tar.gz)

data.title: Allow extensions to change font for source code in editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: It would be really cool to be able to customize the display of my source code a little more generally than just colorization. The ability to apply CSS to editor elements would be fantastic, but individual preferences would be fine with me. As an example of what I mean, this would enable re-styling comments to be in a hand-written font, or have calls to certain functions be extra large. Hopefully this request makes sense, I think it could unlock some really powerful feedback mechanisms, but maybe I'm barking up the wrong tree. Would love to know either way. Thanks VSCode team!

data.title: Deprecate debug type 'node2'
data.body:
In order to smoothen the node debugging experience (see #19650) we should try to deprecate the debug type 'node2' and make it as invisible as possible.

If we cannot deprecate the debug type, we should warn the user when launching a 'node2' debug session (which could be done in the node-debug2 extension code).

data.title: Test: Evolve node2 and node into a single node debugging experience
data.body:
Test for #19650:
complexity: 2

- [x] Windows - @michelkaporin
- [x] OS X - @sandy081
- [x] Linux - @mousetraps 

In this milestone we've started to fold the two node debug extensions 'node-debug' and 'node-debug2' into one (conceptual) extension and eliminated the need for dealing with two debug types ('node' and 'node2'). We call it 'conceptual' extension because there are still two extensions, but we try to hide the 'node-debug2' extension so that the user only sees 'node-debug'. The functionality provided by 'node-debug2' is fully available through 'node-debug' (and the associated debug type 'node').

In this milestone it works like this:

The launch configuration for 'node' supports a new attribute 'protocol' which controls how node-debug uses the old node debugger or the new node debugger.
- **legacy**: node-debug acts like the old node debugger by using the (obsolete) v8 debugger protocol (supported by node versions < v8). In this milestone this is the default if the 'protocol' attribute is missing or if the auto-detection fails.
- **inspector**: node-debug acts like the new node debugger ('node2') by using the inspector protocol (supported by node versions >= 6.3, but not yet supported by electron).
- **auto**: tries to automatically detect the protocol. For configurations of request type 'launch' and if no 'runtimeExecutable' is specified, we try to determine node's version by running node from the PATH with an '--version' argument. If the version is >= 6.9 the new 'inspector' protocol is used. For configurations of request type 'attach' we try to connect with the new protocol and if this works, we use the 'inspector' protocol. We only switch to the new inspector protocol for versions >= 6.9 because of severe problems in earlier versions.

Verify:
- that the 'protocol' attribute works as described above. Try with two versions of node: one that supports only the old protocol and one that supports the old and the new (a version that only supports the new protocol is not yet available). Try with Electron (which only supports the old protocol even in recent versions).
- that the 'auto' mode works reasonable. We will make this mode the default in the future, so we'll have to make sure that users do not run into lots of issues. 
- that if protocol 'auto' is used, a message appears in the debug console that explains how the decision was made.
- the "Node.js v6.3+ (experimental)" does not appear in launch config snippets or in the debug environment selector that appears when there is no launch.json.
- the use of debug type 'node2' in launch configs is flagged as deprecated.

Tipps:
- for testing the 'attach' case, launch a node program for the new inspector protocol with `node --inspect` or `node --inspect=5555` or `node --inspect --debug-brk=5555`

data.title: Feature Request : Adding folders to project like SublimeText
data.body:
In SublimeText there is a feature to adding folders to project main folder that shown in below image.
![add-forlders-to-project](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10684451/23163943/027a0238-f84a-11e6-8452-b57f01b9816d.PNG)

This is a useful feature because I can add Wordpress folder to Wordpress plugin project, so I don't need include Wordpress folder as my main project folder.

With this feature Git can detects my main project folder repository.

Currently when I add Wordpress as main project folder VS Code can not detects my plugin git repository, so I think that by adding this feature this problem can be solved.

Also when I open my plugin folder as main project folder PHP Intellisense extensions can not autocomplete codes of Wordpress because I have not Wordpress folder in my project folder.

Now I am using `Git Project Manager` extension to opening my plugin folder as git repository, but I think that this feature can be useful than using `Git Project Manager` extension approach.

Regards.

data.title: Git operations don't show in reflog history
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS (Xenial Xerus)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make file changes & save
2. Goto Git tab (CTRL + SHIFT + G)
3. Click "clean" button to reset all changes
4. Open terminal and run `git reflog`

Expected:
It should show the VSCode git operations (for example `git reset --HARD`). So you can rollback.
